name: Otolaryngology (ENT) - General

points: High clinic volumes with limited time for comprehensive evaluations (sinus/voice/dizziness)
OR block scarcity and turnover delays limiting surgical access and growth
In-office procedure scheduling bottlenecks (scope, turbinate reduction, ET dilation)
Backlog for audiology and vestibular testing delaying care plans
Unpredictable ED consults (epistaxis, peritonsillar abscess, airway) extending workdays
Pediatric add-ons and after-hours emergencies affecting work-life balance
Variable cross-coverage with head & neck or facial trauma adding intensity
Limited post-call recovery in smaller groups
Insufficient audiology/allergy staffing leading to patient leakage
Lack of dedicated scope techs or image-capture/documentation support
Challenges recruiting experienced ENT RNs/MAs familiar with procedures
Inconsistent support for hearing aid sales, VNG, and vestibular rehab
RVU targets not calibrated to case mix or in-office procedures
Opaque credit for allergy testing/IT or hearing aid revenue
Limited stipends for medical directorships (allergy, audiology, clinic lead)
Mismatch between call burden and compensation
Documentation burden for scoping and procedure notes
Prior auth hurdles for CT sinus, imaging, and advanced meds
Quality metrics and registry reporting competing with clinical time
Multiple EHRs across clinic and hospital settings

motivations: Predictable clinic templates with protected procedure blocks
Adequate OR block time and efficient turnover processes
Robust audiology and allergy programs to support comprehensive care
Transparent compensation for in-office procedures and ancillary contributions
Balanced call schedules with post-call recovery
Updated equipment (endoscopes, towers, image capture, microdebriders) and capital support
Opportunities for leadership (Clinic Lead, Medical Director of Audiology/Allergy)
Geographic and school considerations for family
Teaching opportunities with residents/APPs and ENT service-line development
EHR optimization, scribes, and documentation tools to reduce after-hours work

opening: Tell me about your current ENT practice—clinic/OR mix and typical case spectrum.
What’s driving you to explore new opportunities right now?
What changes would make your next role feel like a clear upgrade?
painDiscovery: You mentioned [pain point]—how does that show up during a typical clinic or OR day?
Where are your biggest bottlenecks—OR access, audiology/allergy capacity, or staffing?
How does call (ED consults, pediatric add-ons) impact your schedule and recovery time?
What tools or staffing would meaningfully reduce your documentation burden?
If you could fix one operational process tomorrow, what would it be and why?
clinical: Scope: adult vs pediatric mix; common procedures (T&A, septoplasty, FESS, thyroid/parathyroid, ear surgery).
In-office procedures: nasal endoscopy/laryngoscopy, turbinate reduction, eustachian tube dilation—what’s your comfort and volume?
Audiology integration: hearing aids, CI referrals, VNG; what support do you need?
Typical clinic volume and ideal template; desired OR block days per week?
Comfort with head & neck cases and trauma call expectations?
Preference for personally performing versus supervising APPs; team composition that works best for you?
Interest in leadership roles (clinic, allergy, audiology) or program-building (voice, sleep, sinus centers)?
How do you prefer to handle post-op care and complex chronic ENT conditions (CRSwNP, Meniere’s, LPR)?
motivation: When you picture your ideal ENT practice, what stands out—OR time, clinic flow, or ancillary support?
What would make a move clearly worthwhile for you and your family in the next 12–24 months?
Rank your top three priorities: schedule predictability, compensation transparency, program resources, location, leadership.
Which trade-offs are acceptable (e.g., slightly higher volume for better OR access or leadership opportunities)?
compensation: Walk me through your current compensation—base, wRVU plan, procedure credit, and any ancillary revenue share.
How should in-office procedures, allergy testing/IT, and hearing aid contributions be recognized?
What mix of base, productivity, and stipends would feel equitable given call and program leadership?

commonChallenges.challenge: OR access is too limited for my surgical volume.
commonChallenges.response: How many block days and what turnover targets would allow you to meet your surgical goals?

commonChallenges.challenge: Call and ED consults are burning me out.
commonChallenges.response: What call cadence and post-call recovery would feel sustainable, and how should compensation reflect that?

commonChallenges.challenge: Audiology and allergy capacity can’t keep up with clinic demand.
commonChallenges.response: What staffing and equipment would let you manage demand and reduce leakage?

commonChallenges.challenge: Compensation doesn’t reflect my in-office procedures or ancillary contributions.
commonChallenges.response: Which elements—procedure credit, allergy, hearing aid revenue—should be explicitly included in your plan?

commonChallenges.challenge: Documentation takes too much time after hours.
commonChallenges.response: Which supports—scribes, templates, image capture—would meaningfully reduce your charting load?

commonChallenges.challenge: I want to keep a general practice without heavy subspecialty call.
commonChallenges.response: What case mix and call structure would maintain breadth while staying sustainable for you?

challengingOpportunities: You prefer outpatient-heavy—if we guarantee OR block with efficient turnover, would that balance your surgical goals and lifestyle?
If call is the major pain point, would defined ED consult windows and true post-call relief make a difference?
If compensation transparency is key, would explicit crediting for in-office procedures and ancillaries meet your needs?
You mentioned limited audiology/allergy capacity—if we build those services with staffing and equipment, would that solve the underlying bottleneck?
